name: Pfizer adds $3.5 billion in first-quarter vaccine sales
introduction: Sales of Comirnaty, Pfizerâs BioNTech-partnered coronavirus vaccine, led the firm to a better-than-expected first quarter, with revenues up 45% at $14.6 billion.
content:
Sales of Comirnaty, Pfizer’s (NYSE: PFE) BioNTech-partnered (Nasdaq: BNTX) coronavirus vaccine, led the firm to a better-than-expected first quarter, with revenues up 45% at $14.6 billion.

Following Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), the firm generated $4.9 billion in net income for the first three months of the year, equivalent to 85 cents per share.

The firm’s coronavirus vaccine, also dubbed BNT162b2, which is the most widely used of all approved vaccines in the USA, added $3.5 billion in revenues. The firm now anticipates $26 billion in sales from the product this year.

The experience working with BioNTech seems to have inspired a strategic shift from the New York-based pharma major, with chief executive Albert Bourla announcing plans to create more vaccines using mRNA technology.

Building on the success of Comirnaty, the firm aims to compete with established vaccines giants such as GlaxoSmithKline (LSE: GSK) and Sanofi (Euronext: SAN) to become a major player in this treatment setting.

Strong financials

Pfizer’s work in combating the novel coronavirus was far from the only positive note in the firm’s first quarter financial results, which reflected a strong performance across the board.

Global revenues from anticoagulant Eliquis (apixaban) were up by a quarter and sales of Vyndaqel (tafamidis meglumine) and Vyndamax (tafamidis) - oral transthyretin stabilizers used to prevent heart failure - up 88%.

Xeljanz (tofacitinib) revenues were also strong, coming in 18% higher on a global basis, primarily driven by 16% growth in the USA, due to higher volumes.

Commenting on the results, Dr Bourla said: “Even excluding the growth provided from BNT162b2, our revenues grew 8% operationally, which aligns with our stated goal of delivering at least a 6% compound annual growth rate through 2025.”

He added: “In addition, we have achieved important clinical, regulatory and commercial milestones across our pipeline and portfolio while also continuing to increase our capacity to supply urgently-needed doses of BNT162b2 to the world.”

Pfizer raised its guidance ranges for 2021 revenues, to between $70.5 and $72.5 billion, up from between $59.4 and $61.4.

Selected product performance

Ibrance (palbociclib) - $1.2 billion, down 1% from $1.2 billion.

Xtandi (enzalutamide) - $267 million, up 28% from $209 million.

Eliquis (apixaban) - $1.6 billion, up 26% from $1.3 billion.

Xeljanz (tofacitinib) - $538 million, up 19% from $451 million.

Inlyta (axitinib) - $229 million, up 36% from $169 million.
